document.docAuthor: Nascimento, Stênio R. S., Lima, Lucas R. C., Mariano, Rodolfo & Azevêdo, Carlos A. S.
document.docTitle: Traverella excelsior Nascimento & Lima & Mariano & Azevêdo 2020, sp. nov.
document.masterDocTitle: New species and stages description of Traverella Edmunds, 1948 (Ephemeroptera Leptophlebiidae) from Northeast Brazil

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: New species and stages description of Traverella Edmunds, 1948 (Ephemeroptera Leptophlebiidae) from Northeast Brazil

mods:name.mods:affiliation: Universidade Estadual do Piauí (UESPI), Campus Heróis do Jenipapo, Laboratório de Biodiversidade, Cep 64280 - 000, Campo Maior, Piauí State, Brazil. lucaslima _ 86 @ hotmail. com; https: // orcid. org / 0000 - 0001 - 5943 - 3351
casazevedo @ yahoo. com. br; https: // orcid. org / 0000 - 0002 - 0503 - 3843

subSubSection.paragraph:
Diagnosis.
Traverella excelsior
sp. nov.
can be distinguished from its congeners by the following differential characters: male imago: 1) forks of MA and MP veins asymmetric, ICu1 basally free ( Fig. 2A ); 2) styliger plate with lateral projections sharpening toward apex and with cavity from the inner base to the apex of forceps, covering almost entirely the penes lobes ( Figs 1D , 2D ); 3) penes lobes with a ventrally projected at apex ( Figs 1E , 2E ); 4) subapical spines with broad base, tapering toward the apex and medially curved and inserted in a groove into each penes lobes ( Fig. 2E ). Nymph: 1) clypeus without an anteromedial projection, lateral margin strongly concave, maximum width of labrum 1.3× maximum width of clypeus; 2) labrum U-shaped with anteromedial emargination; dorsal proximal row with 13–15 long setae interrupted medially; 3) mandible with a median rounded area on inner margin; outer margin basally curved; 4) gills present on segments I–VII tapering gradually, with no lateral tracheation, inner margin with 6–8 filaments along the entire length of gill and outer margin apically with 3–4 filaments.
Description. Male imago (in alcohol). Length: body: 5.9–6.7 mm ; forewing: 6.8–6.9 mm ; hind wing: 1.03–1.2 mm .

Thorax. Pronotum dark brown washed with black, with posterior margin dark brown and, medially with light brown band ( Fig. 1C ). Mesonotum dark brown, except for mediolongitudinal, medioparapsidal and lateroparapidal sutures light brown, posterior scutal protuberance and scuto-scutellar impression dark brown, scutellum light brown ( Figs 1A, C ). Metanotum light brown; pleura yellowish-brown with dark brown sclerites; sternum light brown ( Figs 1A, C ). Wings ( Figs 2 A–C). Membrane hyaline, stained with brown at base. Forewing with yellowish longitudinal veins yellowish and crossveins translucent, forks of MA and MP veins asymmetrics, ICu1 basally free ( Fig. 2A ). Hind wing with hyaline membrane, brown at base, costal projection well-developed, forming acute angle, veins translucent ( Figs 2B, C ). Legs. Forecoxa dark brown, median and posterior yellowish-brown. Trochanters yellowish-brown. Foreleg with femur yellowish-brown with small brown band, washed with black at apex; tarsus yellowish-brown. Mid and hind legs: femora yellowish-brown with dark brown band washed with black at apex; tarsi yellowish-brown.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 1.
Traverella excelsior
sp. nov.
male imago; A) lateral view of imago; B) head (dorsal view); C) thorax and abdomen (dorsal view); D) genitalia (ventral view); E) abdominal segments VII–X (lateral view). Scale bars in mm: A = 2; B, E = 0,5; C = 1; D = 0,2.

FIGURE 2.
Traverella excelsior
sp. nov.
male imago; (A–B) Wings: A) forewing; B) hind wing; C) enlarged hind wing; (D–E) Genitalia: D) ventral view; E) detail of penes, ventral view. Scale bars in mm: A = 2; B = 0,5; D–E = 0,2.

subSubSection.paragraph: Mature Nymph. Length: body, 5.9–6.6 mm ; antenna, 3.6– 3.5 mm ; cerci, 7.1–7.3 mm ; terminal filament, 8.2– 8.7 mm . General coloration brown ( Figs 3–5 ).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 3.
Traverella excelsior
sp. nov.
nymph; A) habitus; B) detail of abdominal sterna; C) lateral view of nymph. Scale bars in mm: A–C = 2.

FIGURE 4.
Traverella excelsior
sp. nov.
nymph; A) labrum, dorsal view; B) hypopharynx, ventral view; C) labium, dorsal view; D) left mandible; E) maxilla, ventral view. Scale bars in mm: A–E = 0,5.

subSubSection.paragraph: Biology. The nymphs were captured inhabiting leaves and rocks about 1 m below the water surface, on the banks of Rio Itapecuru. The river flows through highly impacted agricultural land and pasture. The river receives the wastewaters from Caxias municipality and all communities upstream, and many people use the river for laundry, bathing, and fishing.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 5.
Traverella excelsior
sp. nov.
nymph; A) foreleg; B) middle leg; C) Gill IV; D) hind leg; E) hind tarsal claw. Scale bars in mm: A, B and D = 1; C = 0,5; E = 0,2.

subSubSection.paragraph: Etymology. In memory of the famous comic book writer, Stanley Martin Lieber ‘Stan Lee’ (1922–2018), whose expression “Excelsior!” (word of Latin origin meaning something illustrious, grandiose, majestic) found special popularity.

Holotype :
♂ imago (reared), exuviae mounted on slides, Brazil , Maranhão State , Cax- ias municipality, Pé da Serra , Rio Itapecuru , S05°07’28.51” , W43°33’02.26” ,

.

;
5 ♂ nymphs ( UFVB–EP00195 ), same data as holotype, except
02.ii.2014
, Nascimento , SRS; Gomes , GRD; Diego, DC cols
;

06.xii.2019
, Nascimento , SRS; Jesus , JIS cols
.

Discussion. The male imago of
T. excelsior
sp. nov.
is similar to
T. ( Zonda ) calingastensis
from Western Argen- tina by sharing the same pattern of coloration on body and wings, and styliger plate with broad and paired projections. However, the new species differs from it by having a styliger plate very unusual for the genus, with lateral projections apically pointed and laterally curved, and a small medial projection posteriorly projected. The subapical spine of penes lobe is also uncommon with broad base, tapering toward the apex and medially curved and inserted in a groove into each penes lobe. The nymphal stage is similar to
T. insolita
by the presence of a prominent tusk on galea-lacinia and a row of spine-like setae on the foretibia, and absence of a frontoclypeal projection. They can be distinguished from each other by the ratio of width/length of labrum: 2.8× in
T. insolita
and 2.5× in
T. excelsior
sp. nov.
